content.title: Direct Thrombin Inhibitors
content.summary: Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTIs) are anticoagulants that directly bind to and inhibit thrombin without requiring antithrombin as a cofactor. They are particularly valuable in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia and have predictable pharmacokinetics.
content.definition: A class of anticoagulants that directly bind and inhibit thrombin (factor IIa), independent of antithrombin cofactor activity, blocking both fibrin-bound and free thrombin

thrombin_inhibition.direct_binding: Binds directly to active site and/or exosite of thrombin
thrombin_inhibition.no_cofactor: Does not require antithrombin III (unlike heparin)
thrombin_inhibition.inhibits_both: Blocks both free circulating thrombin AND fibrin-bound thrombin

bivalent.definition: Binds both active site and exosite 1 of thrombin

argatroban.renal_effect: No dose adjustment for renal failure
argatroban.reversal: No specific antidote; short half-life allows effect to wear off

bivalirudin.monitoring: ACT for PCI, aPTT for medical
advantages: Lower bleeding risk than heparin+GP IIb/IIIa in some settings

dabigatran.dose_adjustment: Reduce or avoid in severe renal impairment
dabigatran.monitoring: Not routinely monitored; thrombin time if needed

desirudin_lepirudin.note: Hirudin derivatives; lepirudin withdrawn from market
limitations: Renal clearance (problematic in HIT with renal failure)

agents: Argatroban (hepatic clearance - good for renal failure)
HIT.critical: Must stop all heparin products and switch immediately

PCI.bivalirudin: Alternative to heparin, especially in bleeding risk
PCI.argatroban: Option for HIT patients requiring PCI

VTE_prevention_treatment.dabigatran: FDA-approved for DVT/PE and stroke prevention in AF

ECT_TT.interpretation: Thrombin time very sensitive to dabigatran

laboratory_monitoring.INR_effect: Argatroban falsely elevates INR - complicates warfarin transition

dabigatran.supportive: PCC, activated charcoal if recent ingestion

vs_factor_Xa_inhibitors: Factor Xa inhibitors block upstream in cascade

definition.@value: Anticoagulants that directly bind and inhibit thrombin independent of antithrombin

learning_objectives: Explain the mechanism of action of direct thrombin inhibitors
Compare bivalent and univalent DTI binding
List specific DTIs and their pharmacokinetic properties
Select appropriate DTI for HIT and PCI settings
Describe reversal strategies for DTI anticoagulation
clinical_pearls: DTIs can inhibit clot-bound thrombin (heparin cannot)
Argatroban: hepatic metabolism - good for HIT with renal failure
Argatroban falsely elevates INR - complicates warfarin transition
Bivalirudin has very short half-life (~25 min) - good for procedures
